Hundreds of millions of people use it today. During the Coronavirus outbreak, which affected traditional wholesale distribution networks, Pinduoduo helped farmers sell perishable stock.

Use case: Motivate and enable users to create content
Description: In mid-2020, in the wake of the controversy about TikTok, Facebook moved swiftly to offer financial incentives to TikTok creators with millions of followers, to encourage them to move to Facebook’s Reels; TikTok countered this move with a US $300 million “creative fund” aimed at highly popular creators. TikTok is also an interesting example on how to motivate a community of creators, by making future success on one’s creation less dependent on past successes (the “old money effect” in social media) and more dependent on the actual interest of the community members in the current creation.

Use case: Use mastery as a form of work satisfaction
Description: In consulting firms, Practice Leaders and in general SMEs derive part of their satisfaction from that mastery – and by sharing it with the people around them, as well as obtaining powerful feedback from those networks.
Credentials as an incentive: Methods like Lean Six Sigma, leverage mastery through publicly-recognized credentials to keep people going.
In Wikipedia, mastery is a strong driver for community members’ efforts.

Use case: Use feeling of "Flow" as a performance booster
Description: Flow, the concept developed by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi 117 refers to the positive experience felt by people who are absorbed in an activity they master. The restaurant McDonald’s famously redesigned its kitchen layout and standard operating procedures to enable employees to achieve a certain level of collective flow. In that respect, Significant workflow in large enterprises, starting from early industrial revolution restructuring of assembly line, had some “group flow and mastery” at its root.

Designing incentives in a supermind requires clear and granular choices about collaboration and competition. The same task, performed as a competition, can be off-putting for large groups of people who would prefer it to be a collaboration, and destroy the motivation that’s supposed to build. For instance, design thinking sessions and in general brainstorming practices deliberately reduce the amount of competition in the group, for people to be able to build on each other’s contribution. Conversely, competitions like those performed on Kaggle or MIT Climate CoLab’s include an element of competition to stimulate participation, clearly signaling to participants that their reputational value would increase were they to win.

Use case: Use social capital and trust as drivers of network effectiveness and incentives
Description: Grameen Bank has shown that social networks can enable trust mechanisms that allow provision of credit to previously “unbankable” communities.

Energized, connected systems already exist - think of the success of things like Kaggle.com, TopCoder or Kickstarter that combine both intrinsic (mastery, fame) with extrinsic (monetary prizes, often however, mostly a reinforcement of the intrinsic motivation).

Use case: Collaborate around community based biology in large networks
Description: Including synthetic biology, the operating model is more the one of a movement than a traditional academic collaboration. Supported by MITMediaLab

Use case: Identify role of influencers and people with clout
Description: Influencers and people with significant clout could inject themselves at crucial junctures in the threads and conversations, and visibly endorse or praise people – or simple show with their presence that they matter. Senior executives do that systematically. The use of network analytics and technologies like Microsoft Workplace Analytics can help network influencers to pinpoint the intervention points and be more efficient.

A rich source of energy is the information exhaust which can amplify an individual’s contribution. Companies like Waze understand that well. Waze offers a very balanced ratio between what it gives (guidance enriched by fellow travelers’ actions) and what it asks for (the GPS coordinates of your telephone, and the occasional action to flag an issue on the road).

Use case: Use network based incentives to solve problems
Description: In the DARPA “red balloon challenge”, participating teams competed to find the location of ten red balloons released randomly over a very large territory across the United States. The winning team, an MIT group, successfully used incentives to stimulate participation of thousands of people, not unlike methods used in multi-level marketing.

Use case: Use extrinsic and incentive in enterprise employee networks
Description: Organizational incentives such as key performance indicators associated with bonus payout are frequently deployed on groups of people, not just individuals, to secure collaboration. No wonder that employee performance and employee-engagement software is a fast-developing space, with companies like Kudos, Workhuman (Globoforce), Workstars and others vying for the respective enterprise budgets.

Going beyond traditional ads and platform based payments, Coil.com, supports both organizations and offers end customers the ability to browse all web-monetized content through an extension in the user’s browser.
Legal action crowdfunding – which echoes funding by citizens in Singapore, for instance.

Use case: Allocate time and money to employee projects
Description: CultivateLabs enables companies to give people some time and budget to allocate, in order to crowdfund promising ideas. In some respect this is similar to early prediction markets that were dispensing fictional money to observe which bets employees would take – except that in this case, the time and/or money are real and will be effectively allocated once the employee has made that decision, and the candidate project has achieved a minimum funding level to be approved and funded.

In response to the significant market control of established online companies such as Google, new intermediaries (such as Substack, or its not-for-profit counterpart ghost.org, for newsletter creators) are emerging to provide better incentives to creators.
American crowdfunding platform, covering everything from celebration to expensive cures.
Grantfortheweb.org is notable in its mission as “a fund for the development of open, fair and inclusive standards and innovation in web monetization”.

Kickstarter's structure allows people with specific interests (e.g. art, fashion, consumer electronics, etc) to provide monetary support for what they believe are worthy causes. In return, they receive some extrinsic reward (the finished product) but mostly a strong intrinsic reward, such as “insider” information about the progress of the project. Kickstarter has made the matching of supply and demand for monetary incentive relatively frictionless, so funders aren’t just wealthy patrons of the arts. And because the funders receive strong intrinsic incentives, it enables Significant more risk taking on the part of the entrepreneur – as well as the funding of endeavors that don’t have strong monetary output.
Online sweepstakes
Creator crowdfunding.

In response to the significant market control of established online companies such as Google, new intermediaries (such as Substack, or its not-for-profit counterpart ghost.org, for newsletter creators) are emerging to provide better incentives to creators.
There are new solutions for the generation of granular payment streams from the users to the providers, e.g. those proposed by open-source Webmonetization.org and its web-monetization wallets.
Swiss platform for funding inventors.

Use case: Mechanisms for frictionless distribution of incentives
Description: 0x.org allows for the exchange of tokens enabling the secure allocation of reward to distributed workforces (both human and machines).

Built on the blockchain architecture, commonstack.org, which is intent on “building commons-based microeconomies to sustain public goods through incentive alignment, continuous funding and community governance [through a] library of open-source, interoperable web3 components [that] put effective new tools in the hands of communities, enabling them to raise and allocate shared funds, make transparent decisions, and monitor their progress in supporting the Commons.”

"Crowdfund Capital Advisors (CCA) delivers strategic insights to government agencies, financial institutions, regulators and multilateral organizations seeking to both create and implement innovative strategies to utilize crowdfund investing (CFI) technologies to drive innovation, job creation and entrepreneurship."
Ocean Protocol enables transactions to happen closer to sensitive data, behind protection wall.

Use case: Enable crowdfunding venture rounds through platform
Description: Wefunder and StartEngine are platforms for investing in startups and small businesses.

Harnesses the ability of the market to be rewarded for providing insight, not just transactions. For instance, Gnosis.pm prediction markets conditional tokens (blockchain based), enable more precise risk-adjusted pricing and matching demand with supply of predictions, including the ability to predict, trade, and hold funds.

Use case: Help the "collective healthcare mind remember” solutions
Description: A knowledge feeder also helps the collective mind “remember” what has worked elsewhere. For instance, medical- school instruction, or crowdsourced environments like PatientsLikeMe can help medical communities get smarter about what has worked in specific circumstances in the past, sparing the individuals the need to form those experiences directly. PatientsLikeMe is a particularly interesting example, because of their collaboration started in 2017 with Chinese AI company iCarbonX whose stated intent is to “digitize the components of life”.

Fueled by the incubation of “hypercuration” ideas made by companies like Substack and Medium, in late 2020 and early 2021, a variety of alternative models started emerging. Forums like Clubhouse and Twitter Super Follows showed that smaller audiences, relying on a more intimate connection with the creators, could also be financially attractive and, hopefully, yield more thoughtful, insightful, and civil information feeders.
At the end of 2020, the introduction of Clubhouse created a new hybrid: real-time audio-only conversations, in private invite-only rooms, where (typically) influencers host discussion in which participants can raise hand and intervene. This one-to-many model is de-facto a hybrid between social media (podcasting) and unified communications. While it is too early to tell if this model would be effective, in early 2021 Clubhouse was already valued as a Unicorn.

Use case: Generate a repository of internet page structures
Description: The flow of social media curated for each of us relies on algorithms that examine our Twitter network, or the communities on Reddit or LinkedIn. A repository of free internet page structures is offered by Commoncrawl.org.

Use case: Store and retrieve all world news
Description: To tap into news trends, G-DELT, a global database of published sources, auto-translated from dozens of languages and available as a public resource or through Google Big Query is a great resource. The globally- sourced news repository G-DELT disgorges machine-translated news from thousands of publicly accessible sources worldwide. It has the ability to identify newsworthy actions taken by billions of people: from adaptation to water scarcity, to early detection of potential conflicts due to environmental stress, to surfacing of the perceived popularity and adoption of public policies, the world becomes a petri dish that teams elsewhere can read, avoiding the proverbial reinvention of the wheel.

Google search queries have been used to gain a new perspective on social dynamics. They can identify to the gap between declared and actual behavior (many lie to pollsters, but few lie to a search engine text- input field). Another obvious application is healthcare: Google Health was discontinued in 2011 but examination of search queries haves, for instance, been used to shed light on health needs in the African continent by exploring which demographic segments are interested in certain types of cures.

Use case: Generate realistic and cogent natural language
Description: OpenAI’s GPT-3, a language model trained on one of the largest knowledge datasets in the world, is increasingly able to summarize natural language and other text-based knowledge. Think of it as a “auto-complete” on steroids, but with an unprecedented ability to synthesize information, and even doing so in fascinating ways, for instance by using a specific corpus of data that would, say, enable it to simulate the answers that a person (say, Alan Touring), would provide to a specific question [...] GPT-3 could also radically alter how people write code, by enabling millions to provide plain-English instruction and let the neural network do the rest.

Use case: Generate realistic and cogent natural language
Description: Initially engineered by Google, Transformers are a new architecture that enables computers to understand language with radically improved accuracy, and they’re architecturally the fourth archetypes of neural networks (after convolutional and recurrent neural networks, and multilayer perceptrons).

Use case: Enable physical-environment monitoring through crowdsourced, tech-enabled sensors
Description:
Takingspace.org’s Airbeam enables crowd-based “aircasting”, i.e. the monitoring and analysis of pollution exposure across large groups of people. A competitor of Airbeam, Awair also measures pollution exposure through grassroots contributions. A competitor of Airbeam, Awair also measures pollution exposure through grassroots contributions.
Co-timed with Earth Day 2020, Microsoft launched its “Planetary Computer” project, aimed at collecting, storing and processing (through AI) data sourced across the planet, and make it available to researchers, including citizen scientists.
Meanwhile, Safecast is the collective, citizen-led response to Fukushima’s nuclear reactor failure, when hundreds of DIY radioactivity sensors were deployed by laypeople, enabling a fast response to the crisis. It also deployed IoT devices to detect radiation.

The accuracy of preprint scientific papers and repositories such as Biorxiv and Medrxiv, in an effort to speed up the sharing of information during the Covid-19 emergency, became concerned, so Significant so that MIT Press launched “Rapid Reviews”, a peer-review journal that uses artificial intelligence to curate the most promising papers, and then commission peer reviews in collaboration with University of California Berkeley. The journal is hosted on PubHub.

Arxiv, the grandfather of pre-prints’ repositories started in 1994, has seen tens of millions of downloads, and has spurred the creation of specialized-domain pre-prints, such as PsyArxiv and SocArXiv and then BioArvi and Medrxiv

Use case: Decentralize the measurement of air quality
Description: Project where Google Street View cars measure air quality as they drive through cities.

Use case: Obtain bird images and bird songs to enable tracking of biosphere changes
Description: Cornell University’s eBird is aimed at obtaining pictures (over a million logged so far) and bird songs – which are then run through an AI application called Merlin. The results are then used, among others, by scientists, like in the case of State of India’s Birds.

Use case: Add environmental data to geospatial data layers
Description: Environmental Insight Explorer (EIE)  offers the ability to append environmental data, measured or estimated, to geospatial layers enabling further insight for both organizations and end users. One of the first use cases is to help cities manage pollution.

Use case: Apply image recognition software to monitor environmental changes
Description: Grevy’s Zebra Trust has the Wild Me platform to support volunteer and scientists rallies in a wildlife conservancy area. The emerging risk that these platforms need to manage is that they may inadvertently give poachers a way to find animals. Authentication and identity control can be a solution, not unlike in other parts of the web.

Use case: Use citizen Observatories projects to monitor agricultural developments
Description: Expanding on GEOSS (Global Earth Observation System of Systems), the Citizen Observatories projects are funded by the European Union. One of them is GROW (soil-moisture citizen observatory) aimed at climate change and including scientists, NGOs, communities and individuals. Computer vision sifts through mixed-source (people, machines) imagery from both people and machines to enable better agricultural decisions at OneSoil.ai.

Use case: Scale the Mapping and sharing of observations of biodiversity
Description: The iNaturalist community (an effort run by the California Academy of Science and the National Geographic Society) uses specialized computer vision specialized classifiers to allow the mapping and sharing of observations of biodiversity across the globe using a free mobile app and has contributed more than 60 million observations of more than 300,00 species.
In the UK, a network of sensors tracks biodiversity degradation.

Use case: Map human responses to adverse weather events
Description:
The Mexican state of Tabasco has been mapping human behavior in response to adverse weather events, combining mobile and other sensor data, to pinpoint needs and interventions. The effort is part of the “UN Global Pulse”, harnessing support from the respective UN agency, the World Food Program, and local constituencies. 
A comparable effort is at play in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, where the Ramani Huria project, (based on OpenStreetMap – an open sourced mapping effort), helps local communities map relevant infrastructure and land features especially in informal human settlements.

Use case: Use image recognition software for biosphere tracking (animals in the wild)
Description: Oregon-based Wild Me's software provides image recognition to cameras positioned in the wild – so that individuals can be tracked as they move in their habitat.

An array of companies are using crowds to train algorithms. Mozilla’s Common Voice initiative uses crowdsourced voices to train speech recognition software. Captcha, the now- famous method to enable authentication for user sign in with the objective of limiting automated login and related misuse of internet assets, was initially conceived as a clever mechanism to use people to help machines tag visual content from millions of scanned books that computerized character recognition couldn’t decipher. It is in a way the largest crowdsourcing effort in the world. Amazon used it for tagging millions of pictures with humans – which spawned Amazon Mechanical Turk, the grandfather of crowdsourcing platforms.

Use case: Create maps and correct computer-created maps
Description: Europe’s BlackShore.eu uses gamified crowdsourcing to create maps; it operates in a similar space as OpenStreetMap

Use case: Generate Multisourced / crowdsourced maps for healthcare
Description: Healthmap.org “delivers real-time intelligence on a broad range of emerging infectious diseases for a diverse audience including libraries, local health departments, governments, and international travelers. HealthMap brings together disparate data sources, including online news aggregators, eyewitness reports, expert- curated discussions and validated official reports, to achieve a unified and comprehensive view of the current global state of infectious diseases and their effect on human and animal health. Through an automated process, updating 24/7/365, the system monitors, organizes, integrates, filters, visualizes and disseminates online information about emerging diseases in nine languages, facilitating early detection of global public health threats.”

Who / What: Nippon Foundation and GEBCO Seabed project
Description: The Nippon Foundation and GEBCO Seabed project, launched in 2017, has by now mapped over 10% of the Earth’s oceanic floors. The next phase will include crowdsourcing of data by appending echo- sounding equipment to all sorts of vessels, based on their routes. Along similar lines, swarms of bots could possibly one day act as sensor networks canvassing larger spaces in a dynamic, adaptable manner.

For over a decade, OpenStreetMap's thousands of volunteers have toiled to provide an open source alternative to commercial geo-mapping, further annotating and correcting computer-vision-detected terrain. Additional uses of this networked intelligence include rapid re- mapping of areas impacted by natural disasters.
Bellingcat uses crowdsourced information for investigative journalism. It also runs workshops to train people on using web resources for research investigation.

Use case: Curate content as an information feeder for learners
Description: In a learning supermind the content curated acts as an information feeder for the learners. Specialized curation and learning portals identify, sort and allocate the content to the right places, such as a learning platform like EdCast, or a central knowledge repository built on a common Microsoft SharePoint.

Use case: Allow experts to expand their networks externally and internally
Description: Experts have sources of information – from trade contacts to client engagements – and can tap into their pre-existing networks. The networked intelligence model enables them to expand that network both externally (as knowledge managers help comb external sources more thoroughly) and internally. The latter is quite important. Thousands of people can now provide the experts feedback from the natural experiments that they carry out daily. They also re-direct to the experts any interesting tidbits of knowledge that they might come across. As a backbone to all of this, multiple Microsoft Teams channels facilitate the interaction between experts and knowledge managers.

Use case: Scraping social media to find war equipment
Description: The Syrian Archive is an initiative using tools that scrapes social media feeds to detect and classify imagery pertaining to war equipment, with the intent of documenting and making searchable evidence of war crimes. The neural net AI curates and classifies information automatically.

Use case: Surface the ideas of a community
Description: Allourideas.org is a survey tool that can be administered through wiki, with a in-built statistical analysis that lends itself to deciding between options during a debate.

Use case: Use bots for facilitation of democratic debate
Description: Apptivism.org uses custom-built bots to engage constituencies and collect their feedback.

Use case: Use surveys and polling as curation engines
Description: A knowledge feeder is, at its core, a curation engine. That is, an environment that makes the timely retrieval and dissemination of relevant and salient content frictionless. Most teams and all organizations have some sort of process to do this – the problem is, they’re very often amateurish at it. Semi-synchronous polling, for instance on sensitive topics during employees townhalls, is possible through tools like Feedy. Companies like SurveyMonkey have made the administration of simple questionnaires online (asynchronous) extremely easy.

An example of participatory platform for democratic process, that combines traditional survey and AI-curated collaboration. The US department of state used a combination of traditional survey and AI-curated collaboration with its citizens to improve its passport services in 2016, through a participatory platform called insights.us - the platform is now available to cities and government agencies.

Use case: Provide insight on the real-time views of large groups
Description: Synchronous, real-time polling is possible through a variety of collaboration platforms. For more insight on the real-time views of large groups, tools like remesh.ai can be useful.
Synchronous, real-time polling is possible through a variety of collaboration platforms, like videoconferencing technologies e.g. Zoom, Skype for Business, WebEx etc.

Use case: Enable telephone polling through text messaging
Description: Ureport.in enables polling through telephone messaging, thus making it accessible in developing countries where internet connectivity is hard to achieve.
CB Insights is a natural language processing engine that uses advanced analytics; it monitors the venture-capital backed startup space and aggregates insights across company news

Identifying the words that describe the space being searched (the semantic network that delineates ontologies e.g. words that are ideally MECE - mutually exclusive and hopefully collectively exhaustive) can be done either heuristically by asking experts to map out the words and clustering them in groups, or even analytically by extracting so-called “entities” by using R or Python NLTK - or more specialized entity visualizers like DisplaCy - to identify words recurrence in typical content.

Listening posts can be created, typically through social media tools like Feedly, Hootsuite, and Tweetdeck, but also by giving internal users, typically subject matter experts, the ability to act as “level-1 curators” who, by virtue of their own network, can act as initial filters that complement the listening posts.

Use case: Combine human- and machine-sourced text, images, audio
Description: Developed in Qatar, the Crisis Computing group combines multiple sources of text and image data, as well as audio streams, both crowd and machine sourced – in the case of “First Alert” system it uses them to highlight potential crises early. Elsewhere, Dataminr.com combines multiple sources of text and image data, as well as audio streams, both crowd and machine sourced – in the case of “First Alert” system it uses them to highlight potential crises early.

Use case: Enable a search engine for environmental data and resources
Description: Some search engines are customizable and can be turned into usefully curated sources. Dataplanet is a customizable search engine that focuses on environmental data and resources, like WRI.org.

Who / What: Google DataSet, Google Scholar, Semanticscholar.org, Iris.ai
Use case: Enable search engines for scientific literature
Description: Engines focused on academic papers include Google DataSet, Google Scholar, and Semanticscholar.org. At a broader scale, Iris.ai focuses on facilitating scientific literature review and helps the discovery by offering the user a structuring of the semantic fields related to the search query, hence enabling the combination of papers derived from various disciplines.

Curation engines that aggregate content through a combination of human and AI intervention also exist (e.g., Curata but also competitive intelligence tools like XiQ.io or technologies like Discover.ai). The individual person’s ability to efficiently collect and distribute curated knowledge is also the object of recent developments, for example through Factr.

Kaggle, the data science contest community, was used during the COVID-19 pandemic to write natural language processing algorithms helping scientists interpret insights emerging from research done around the world.
Citibeats.net have specialized in mining people’s opinion to help cities and public organizations extract insights from their constituencies.
IoT devices that provide additional data at often marginal cost can be consolidated through technologies like DescartesLabs to facilitate research and analysis.

Use case: Deploy IoT and other sensors to discover "ground truth" data
Description: Companies like Premise.com offer “ground truth services” in spaces as different as logistics and movement monitoring and risk and they’re used for private, government and international development purposes (for instance, to obtain fresh data about Zika’s virus spread). The platform enables on- ground operators to perform data surfacing tasks.

Use case: Collect local feedback and input for analysis and crisis management
Description: Zencity.io is a solution for city-specific collection of feedback and input, enabling local-level analysis and even support to crisis management.

Bridgit.io (in alpha version as of January 2020) enables people to annotate web objects to manually create knowledge graphs. An additional possible use of some of these technologies and the related network intelligence is fact checking

Use case: Enable analysis of complex, distributed web based information
Description: With the advances in Natural Language Processing, machines are getting better at helping humans make sense of connections between elements of large content sets – as in the example of Quid.com or Forestreet that can map technology market landscapes and draw connections between market participants and related technologies

Use case: Annotate text to provide better metadata
Description: Human curators can also use web text annotations tools, like getMemex.com, effectively appending metadata to text parcels of browsing history, in a way that’s somewhat like what Amazon Kindle allows to do on kindle-format books.

Use case: Search companies or topics, supported by humans in the review workflow
Description: golden.com that provides accurate semantic search on companies or topics of interest, for use in consulting, investment or financial services for example. The company Golden in particular has emphasized the synergy between machine and human curators, by enabling workflows allowing editors to improve content quality.

A more collaborative approach to web bookmarking is taken by hypothes.is, that enables communities (for instance, academics, teachers, publishers or journalists) to tag and annotate documents, and discuss them online – providing not only an information feeder but the beginning of a collaboration platform.

Big data analytics languages like Python are already equipped with extensions to mine social media data. For instance, for Python, Tweepy enables it to connect relatively simply to Twitter’s API and analyze its natural language.

Use case: Identify patterns in scientific literature for Covid19
Description: In 2020, BenevolentAI came into the limelight for using machine learning and other AI techniques to identify patterns in existing literature through knowledge graphs. As stated on their website “in the face of the growing global health crisis, BenevolentAI set up a specialist scientific team and launched an investigation using its drug discovery platform to identify approved drugs which could potentially stop the progression of COVID-19, inhibit the cytokine storm and reduce the inflammatory damage associated with this disease. Benevolent’s research findings were published in [scientific journals] as a potential treatment with both anti-viral and anti-inflammatory properties, for COVID-19 patients admitted to hospital prior to the development of critical lung damage.”

Use case: Scan entire documents and finds relevant materials irrespective of their links to other websites
Description: Omnity.io challenges’ the premise of Google’s traditional search (based on citations and connections) to enhance the search of relevant information. Omnity doesn’t need keywords, as it is able to scan entire documents (for example, research notes) and find relevant materials on the web, irrespective of the amount of links to other websites. While Google has enhanced its search engines through knowledge graphs that enable semantic search, its algorithms still significantly reliy on web links because of the advertising value of well-connected web real estate.

Use case: Discover trends through knowledge graphs and automated data exploration
Description: SparkBeyond launched in 2019 an automated data exploration technology that sifts through multiple data sources (web, patents, news etc.) and visualizes ideas that are connected to each other (co-occurring entities), hence facilitating the mining of potential solutions to existing problems: think about being able to quickly query that global corpus of knowledge, largely a curation of human-generated ideas, to find solutions to pressing problems – from disposal of plastics to reducing fossil-fuel energy consumptions for residential cooling. Quid.com, iProva and Forestreet work in similar spaces.

Use case: Analyze scientific and innovation literature and detect of patterns
Description: US Department of Energy’s Berkeley National Lab used NLP to create word-based bodies of text vectors in its word2vec (machine learning) algorithm, which proved to be able to predict material science’s advances

Who / What: Airtable, Aodocs, Bloomfire, Fireflies.ai, Humap, Notion, Slab, Slapdash
Description: Largely thanks to new cloud and AI technology, documentation and knowledge management technology is a dynamic space, with a variety of best-of-breed players also complementing and competing with the traditional enterprise software vendors – see examples such as Notion, Bloomfire, Slapdash, Slab, Aodocs, Fireflies.ai, Humap, and Airtable.

Use case: Enhance search and combine concepts from documents
Description: Knowledge management systems are increasingly complemented by what “insight engines”, that effectively enhance the search and combination of concepts excerpted from the available documents.
Epistemonikos, used by the government of Chile to set new health guidelines based on the latest evidence, uses machine learning to identify reevant reviews in the respective scientific literature.

Use case: Deliver quality scientific content unconstrained by the traditional scientific publishing model
Description: Project Aiur’s objective is to create an open access to quality-controlled content that isn’t restricted through the traditional publishing model and has launched a bitcoin offering to incentivize scientists to collaborate in peer-reviews, hence disrupting the access to scientific information.

Use case: Search and reading of full-text patents
Description: Google Patents enables the search and reading of full text of patents around the world, as well as identifying prior articles in non- patent literature.

The BP oil spill on the US Gulf Coast in 2010 triggered a networked intelligence response, where groups of citizens armed with simple tools (such as aerial images captured by balloons to capture aerial imagery, combined with other information sources) initiated a process of monitoring and decision support processes that enhanced public response to that crisis.

In 2016, Mexico City “open- sourced” PublicLab input to their city’s constitution, where contributions from hundreds of thousands of people were translated into legal language by a central committee. Madrid are experimenting along the same lines, as is Reykjavik with its Better Reykjavik program.
After the BP oil spill on the US Gulf Coast in 2010 triggered a networked intelligence response, the resulting platform, PublicLab.org, has been adapted and used elsewhere in the world.
New crowdsourcing businesses like software community TopCoder have shown the value of specialized workflows and in orchestrating collaboration.

Use case: Enable collaboration for small-scale farmers in Africa
Description: In Africa, Wefarm.co helps millions of small-scale farmers to connect with each other – both through web and SMS - and exchange solutions to their questions.

Its intent is to find solutions for each of the 17 sustainable development goals (SDGs). Each room, initially physical and increasingly virtual, is a breakout space staffed by a cross-section of skills capabilities, and authorities.

Use case: Collaborate to convey emotions and foster coping
Description: Collaboration can be created to convey emotions into art to foster coping. One of the best examples is the design of the New York City’s 9/11 Memorial, intended to memorialize the trauma the city suffered in 2001. The initial proposals from architects and experts around the world had been deemed unable to reflect the true feelings and hence not fit for purpose. The final incarnation of the Memorial is heavily influenced by the voices of communities impacted, in a stunning work that sourced contributions such as soundscapes from ordinary people.

Use case: Deliver a vision for the future, centered around art, and culminating in one-week festival
Description: The yearly Burning Man festival is organized by Black Rock City Limited Liability Company, which uses similar models for other activities. The festival today congregates 70,000 people and has been running since 1986. People build and then completely dismantle a temporary city in the desert, including its infrastructure, security, food and shelter – respecting a strict “leave no trace” credo inspired by sustainable-development ideals. It is a great demonstration of how agilely coordinated bottoms-up activities can deliver complex systems at scale. Burning Man’s experience is portable for instance to urban planners, refugee camps, and generally city planning.

A marketplace of learning-by-doing opportunities allows learners to consolidate memorization of the learning curriculum by executing small projects in mostly virtual settings. They leverage Microsoft Office 365 including Teams, as well as the core functionality of a Learning Experience Platform (Edcast). The latter also facilitates collaboration by enabling fluid feedback from the learners on specific parts of the curriculum.

Use case: Employees learn with others, by harnessing experts and other learners
Description: Professional services firm need to engaged in up-skilling and re-skilling large workforces at scale. The role of collaboration platforms is paramount. Team members worked from separate offices or from home. External contractors flexibly came and went. Being effective in these conditions hinged on several technology platforms. For instance, all synchronous parts of sprints and scrums took place on Zoom, with widespread use of virtual whiteboards and Microsoft Teams. Meetings led by experts used the same videoconferencing technology with an emphasis on real-time chat discussions, virtual room breakouts, and instant polls that gave SMEs rich input from the learners. SMEs themselves leveraged community sites built on Microsoft SharePoint and Teams.

Who / What: Asana, Basecamp, Hive, Taskade, Unito, Workfront, Wrike
Description: Software in the “collaborative workspace management” attempt to streamline somewhat repetitive and even project-based work that doesn’t fit squarely in a traditional workflow – examples in that space include Wrike, Workfront, Asana, Hive, Unito, Taskade, and Basecamp, as well as other enterprise social media

Use case: Improve AI quality through human micro-judgment
Description: Using humans to label data that then is served up to artificial intelligence algorithms

Use case: Obtain basic help for the home through a marketplace of specialized contractors
Description: Hyperconnectivity and the ability to inventory and quality-control millions of people at minimal marginal cost has changed its dynamics radically, effectively surfacing the cognitive surplus of millions of people and reshaping many jobs. Platforms have in many respects created the current “gig economy” movement, and they increasingly show specialization of roles where very specific expertise is harnessed in a way that wasn’t possible before – an idea first publicized by MIT’s Malone and colleagues in 2011

Hyperconnectivity and the ability to inventory and quality-control millions of people at minimal marginal cost has changed its dynamics radically, effectively surfacing the cognitive surplus of millions of people and reshaping many jobs. Platforms have in many respects created the current “gig economy” movement, and they increasingly show specialization of roles where very specific expertise is harnessed in a way that wasn’t possible before – an idea first publicized by MIT’s Malone and colleagues in 2011

The mission is to connect people who have unusually specialized insight with seekers of that insight. For instance, professional services and consulting firms, as well as financial services ones, utilize their services to connect with experts for a few hours, to ask pointed questions that can help validate or disprove their hypotheses.

Idea management platforms are built to streamline and optimize the otherwise messy flow of idea input and refinement. They have slight differences, especially in terms of additional services that they offer, but all of them have some ability to reach out to potential participants, display the challenges for which solutions are sought, and shape the workflow of input from the participants.
Focused on consultation, engagement and co-creation with citizens to invigorate participation in democratic and public action.

Who / What: Hunchbuzz, Ideadrop, Ideascale, Mindpool, Qmarkets, Spigit, Wazoku, Assembl
Description: Idea management platforms are built to streamline and optimize the otherwise messy flow of idea input and refinement. They have slight differences, especially in terms of additional services that they offer, but all of them have some ability to reach out to potential participants, display the challenges for which solutions are sought, and shape the workflow of input from the participants. Spigit for instance has been behind one of the most successful idea funnels known – AT&T’s TIP. Assembl Bluenove uses AI to categorize content collected from the community, before it is further analyzed by humans.

Who / What: Innocentive, GeniusLink (GE), MIT Futures Colab, MIT Solve, PixelUK (Deloitte), Polyplexus
Use case: Find solutions to challenges through specialized communities
Description: Innocentive is one of the most established communities, and is famously behind Significant of NASA’s open innovation efforts. Geniuslink, ideated by General Electric shares some of the same tenets. MIT Solve, on the other hand, is a competition that seeks community-based innovation that can enable inclusion and shared prosperity. Other examples include MIT's FUtures CoLab, OpenIdeo, Pixel UK (ideated by Deloitte), and Polyplexus (developed by DARPA, whicih is also known as being at the inception of the original internet protocol), whcih combines open-innovation collaboration with Delphi-style expert-community predictions.

Use case: Offer learning options through a marketplace
Description: The learning content marketplace Teachable allows creators to generate and sell to an audience of millions of learners.

An organizational construct used by Amnesty International which uses its volunteers in Amnesty Decoders, for instance in Decode Darfur which asked participants to identify destroyed areas in the settlements of Darfur using satellite images. Salient characteristics of Amnestty Decoders are: a) annotated data sets created by crowds; b) clustering of human language inputs; c) automated translations; d) automated classification of visual objects. A specific use case is "Troll Patrol" that targets social media misinformation and obfuscation.

Scistarter.org added a list of COVID-19 specific challenges during the emergency. Among many others, its GalaxyZoo project (using volunteers to classify galaxies based on deep- space telescope imagery) has inspired the very birth of crowdsourcing. It now covers projects in fields as diverse as arts, biology, climate, history, language, literature, medicine, physics, social science and, indeed, space. In these environments, the collaboration is mostly structured, and text based. Forms follow workflows and allow for attachments and links to add flexibility.

Use case: Foster peer-to-peer community of developing-economy farmers
Description: More than a million people use Wefarm.co in Kenya and Uganda, with over 40,000 questions answered every day. Using the technology platform is very simple and is also possible through SMS for those who don’t have access to internet. Interestingly, natural language processing is utilized to facilitate the exchanges in three regional languages in addition to English.
Neureka is an app intended to engage laypeople in helping scientists better understand neurological conditions such as dementia by having them play a game.
The Phylo DNA puzzle (from Canada’ McGill and some Canadian governmental agencies), through which large numbers of people identify alignments in clusters of genetic data.
The recent “Planetary Computer” initiative at Microsoft is also part of the gamification trend, this time with Microsoft Azur’s significant resources behind it.

Quantum Moves - This game from the University of Aarhus in Denmark, through which path-choices by game players create potential paths for laser beams moving sub-atomic particles in experimental environments
UN-Habitat, Microsoft’s Mojang (maker of online game Minecraft) enrolled thousands of people in thirty countries brainstorm on the layout of their neighborhoods.

Who / What: Skype, Cisco Webex, Adobe Connect, Citrix GoToMeeting, Google Hangouts, BlueJeans, Zoom, Around, Fuze, Lifesize, Loom, Owl, Starleaf, TechSmith, Hopin
Description: Unified communications are an obvious collaboration environment, specifically catering for synchronous or near-real-time (e.g. chat) interactions.  These interactions are important because many people tend to be more productive and creative when they can bounce off thoughts with each other synchronously (mirror neurons may have something to do with it). This technology space has seen significant advances in the last decade, starting with the disruption that Skype introduced into the telecom industry, but also with entrants competing successfully. The recent coronavirus emergency boosted the adoption of these tools, especially as the cloud- based version of them was already extensively used in organizations, enabling scalability while maintaining an appropriate level of security.

Use case: Improve quality of experience during video calls
Description: One significant problem of video-based communications is the misalignment between gaze and camera, an effect that makes people interpret the other person’s behavior as less engaged compared to in-person meetings. The loss of personal engagement affects motivation and possibly reduces the effect of so-called “mirror neurons” that are thought to play a role in enhancing problem solving in groups. Solutions will be brought to market in the future, for example through Apple introducing eye correction software for FaceTime.

Google launched simultaneous earbuds intended to automatically translate language between two or more people in an in-person meeting – and while the current results are not effective enough for professional use, they will soon be close enough, especially for groups with mixed proficiency of language.

Use case: Use AI-based noise cancelling software for improved synchronous collaboration
Description: Audio and video have improved so Significant that traditional videoconferencing equipment has come under siege, and the network of people able to access these tools has increased exponentially. Additional capabilities being deployed now are simultaneous captioning where the speaker’s language is transcribed in real time to facilitate the understanding for non-native speakers. AI-based noise canceling such as Krisp.ai eliminates any frequency but the speaker’s voice, greatly improving the experience.

Since 2018, Microsoft has been actively promoting its real time translation of spoken word during Skype sessions, has added automated subtitling to PowerPoint presentations (Presentation Translator - which uses the language corpus from the presentation itself to enrich its vocabulary)

Since 2018, Microsoft has been actively promoting its real time translation of spoken word during Skype sessions, has added automated subtitling to PowerPoint presentations (Presentation Translator - which uses the language corpus from the presentation itself to enrich its vocabulary)

Use case: Deliver simultaneous translation manned by human translators for improved synchronous collaboration
Description: Zoom videoconferencing has enabled simultaneous translation manned by human translators (professionally certified contractors working for a third party translation company) to enable real time translation between critical languages such as English, Chinese, Russian, and German. In the zoom example, human translators are automatically connected to upcoming meetings in real time, as part of an additional service that Zoom subscribers can purchase.

Journalist and entrepreneur Azeem Azhar’s Exponential View media source, which includes a podcast in collaboration with Harvard Business Review, is synergistic with a newsletter as well as a community of thought leaders run on Slack. The three elements reinforce each other.

Who / What: Microsoft Teams, Jamm, Embryo, Pragli, Remotion, Sococo, Sidekick, Tandem, Teemly, gather.town, workadventu.re
Use case: Use presence indicators to improve synchronous collaboration
Description: Tools like Microsoft Teams have integrated “presence” indicators that show individual people’s current status (e.g. busy in a meeting), so that others can reach out at the appropriate time. Other tools (Jamm, Embryo, Pragly, Remotion, Sococo, Sidekick, Tandem, Teemly among others) have even more directly focused on the design of that spontaneous encounter experience, trying to provide additional ways that people can “locate” each other in a digital/physical space to trigger interactions. Often integrated with tools such as Microsoft Office and Slack, the ultimate objective is to replicate a “virtual office”, or as analysts Gartner calls them, “ambient virtual meetings”.

Use case: Facilitate logistics of scheduling synchronous collaboration
Description: Companies like doodle.ai and X.ai have started attacking the problem to make the user experience a lot more intuitive (for instance using email’s natural language). Other applications that integrate with Microsoft Outlook, and Microsoft themselves are actively working at the problem, to eliminate the labor-intensive work of finding common slots. Limitations due to information security restrictions will likely soon be resolved, and the only constraint will be user awareness. It is probable that one of the most useful applications of AI will then be the work of finding common slots that minimize the inconvenience for all participants.

Who / What: Mattermost, SAP Jam, Jive, Basecamp, Khoros, Telligent, Vanilla Forums, LumApps, Unily, HigherLogic, Tribe, Circle.so
Description: Community and social media management software that makes it easy for marketing & support teams to deliver the best customer experiences, each with their own slight specialization, depending on the type of community, for use within the organization, outside of it, or in a hybrid model. Interestingly, Facebook has also made some steps into space with their Workplace product. Many of these solutions started with asynchronous communications, but increasingly added synchronous capabilities such as video and voice.

Use case: Enable synchronous collaboration through shared data repositories
Description: Tools that enable collaboration by allowing multiple users access to documentation.
Flexible editors like Coda.io, that combine text with basic database, workflow and other types of editing to create flexible process guidance for teams working on the same sheet

Who / What: Discord, Dialpad, Quill, Spike, Threads, Yac
Use case: Enable collaboration through messaging and chat
Description: Technologies can be combined to cater for varied collaboration needs revolving around the use of text. Messaging and chat represent one of the older categories, but there’s a rich and vital supply of best-of-breed applications, with distinctive feature including security and ease of use, as well as the ability to share voice messages seamlessly.
Long-form text editors allow contributions from multiple authorized users.

Spreadsheet editors allow contributions from multiple authorized users. Airtable was used to catalog COVID-19 community based and crowdsourced solutions and has also been used to create small open source reusable utilities, such as appointment setting for business-to-consumer services.
Blogging tools and blog editors can allow collaboration via simple commenting features.
Figma enables groups of people to collaborate on design projects and uses AI to enhance their contributions.

Who / What: iThoughts, Kumu.io, Mindmeister, TheBrain.com, Mental Modeler
Use case: Create collaborative mindmaps to enable collective structuring of ideas
Description: Mindmaps help create outlines of documents. Companies like iThoughts, Kumu.io and Mindmeister allow collaboration in this largely text-based format. These cater for mostly text type entries, but do allow for attachments and links. TheBrain.com offers a more expansive vision that leverages mindmap-type relationships for more than just text – the result is possibly less intuitive than the typical mindmap software. While hyperscale collaboration may not be fully possible on these tools, they are quite useful to capture the interplay between components of a supermind, hence enabling a better understanding of the combined effects of different elements of a network. Mental Modeler is one such tools.

Use case: Use voice dictation to speed up asynchronous collaboration
Description: It is likely that in the future we will rely less on keyboards, because of AI’s significantly improved accuracy of voice-to-text, which in turn will dramatically increase the quantity of text (if not necessarily the quality) that humans can produce.

Use case: Use co-editing tools to improve scientific writing
Description: Specialized tools exist for scientific long form writing, namely papers where the citation burden needs to be managed. Overleaf, offering LaTex support, is one such tool. MIT PubPub is an attempt to create a text environment allowing for large scale annotation by a broader, typically scientific, community.

Who / What: Padlet.io, Mural.ly, Miro, Jamboard, Klaxoon, Stormboard, Mentimeter, Slido, ThinkTank.net
Use case: Uve virtual walls enabling synchronous or asynchronous creativity processes
Description: Virtual post-it notes (the workhorse of creativity sessions) can be generated, modified and moved by groups of roughly up to 50 people. Padlet.io, Mural.ly, Miro, Jamboard, Klaxoon and Stormboard are some options here. These cater for mostly text type entries but do allow for attachments and links, but they also accommodate other content. Dynamic, real-time input and visualization of text by groups of people is supported by tools like Mentimeter, Slido, or ThinkTank.net.

Use case: Use virtual whiteboards for facilitating synchronous creativity processes
Description: Synchronous screen sharing like the Zoom whiteboard is conveniently available on its IOS application, hence allowing the use of the intuitive Apple Pencil on an iPad. This is a marked improvement from previous options, such as the use of screen sharing of documents (like PowerPoint) while using optic pens such as Wacom’s that while precise, have a steeper learning curve for the casual user.

Specifically conceived for use for local government or smaller countries, consensus.ai harnesses “verified signals gathered from citizens in tight feedback cycles to help governments interpret sentiment as it evolves”.

Use case: Debate platforms for civil society deliberation
Description: US government’s Crowdlaw is an attempt to engage broader constituencies in the legislative process.

Use case: Planning and budgeting of consultations with citizens
Description: Decidim.org enables participatory planning, budgeting, assemblies support as well as consultations of citizens and networked communications.

Deliberatorium, DebateGraph, Kialo, atstakegame.org, D-agree.com, Changeview.com, Jenparle (FR), Yourpriorities (IS), Civocracy, D-agree. On these platforms, opposing point of views are discussed in civil and constructive manners to enable the formation of better, more cohesive positions.

Prediction platforms that combine the opinion of people have been around since the early 2000s, for instance in the form of “prediction markets”177 where individuals can “bet” on specific outcomes (like the future trend in a market or the success of a new product) and the platform’s algorithms combine and weigh the results. Companies like Eli Lilly, IBM and Google have all used them extensively in the past to obtain “signals” to improve their development of new solutions. IBM’s alphaWorks used to track downloads of “alpha” (i.e. very early release) solution to predict future demand. Eli Lilly identified many MDs and PhDs who proved extremely far sighted in predicting future drug’s commercial performance.

Who / What: Ethelo.com, democracyos.org, partiunon.org, bangthetable.com, decisiontree.io, choiclaweb, Airesis, Occupy.here, Loomio.org, liquidfeedback.org
Description: Decision-making after debate is the focus of other applications which can be used for engaging stakeholders and teams; or enables feedback and voting on motions
Horizonstate.com is a “secure ballot system” based on blockchain distributed-ledger technology.

A different model is used by Pol.is (also used in Taiwan’s extensive public consultation platform), where the points of view of the various constituencies in an organization are plotted against each other on a map, to show signs of convergence or significantly spread out opinions. A somewhat similar approach is adopted by Crowdscope.com. Consider.it is another examples of tool for public-good entities to post questions and receive feedback.

Who / What: Tapvote.org, Delib.net, Common Ground for Action
Description: Platforms for public deliberation online.

Prediction platform based on possible use of blockchain technology to allow for a broad range of queries. In 2018 Augur.net, the first decentralized prediction market based on the Ethereum platform was launched, hinting at possible use of blockchain technology to allow for a broader range of queries, unlike the fixed ones that normal prediction websites like BetFair allow.

Betting applications have leveraged some of the prediction markets ideas, and some of them have been quite successful, like in the case of Betfair, Smarkets and Kalshi. The latter in particular has received authorization from US regulators for running uncapped-value betting events, in an attempt to make it a more mature financial instrument.
Crowdsmart.io applies a combination of expert member community with natural language AI to predict startup or new-venture success

Predictions based on employee crowd judgment has been used extensively in companies like Ford, Tchibo, Best Buy, Siemens and others – on a range of topics from sales forecasts to project overrun early warning.
Metaculus.com and Hypermind.com (open forecasts) or Tinycast can be deployed by enterprises and other organizations to research specific topics.

Polymarket is another Ethereum based player. While it is unclear how successful its direction has been to date, given the difficulty for a market to create enough liquidity to support itself, the idea of making market for predictions holds the potential of creating a paradigm shift, in that market structures can be disaggregated into smaller units and made significantly more scalable.

the use of prediction markets hasn’t grown as one would have expected given those early successes. Prediction markets’ challenge is not in the process or technology – it is in embedding it into the fabric of strategic decision-making so that it doesn’t become anecdotal. In fact, it is hard to maintain an active group of contributors if the model is seen as a one-off, and the strategy, marketing or R&D departments don’t use it consistently. Publicly available providers that leverage that model now exist - see Predictit.org, MindPool and Metaculus for instance.
Evidencio enables users to get all relevant medical prediction models from a single online library.

GitHub, acquired by Microsoft, is a thriving example of collaboration collective code enhancement and reusability through a clever form of collective revision control based on its now famous forking and committing (indeed, Linus Torvald worked on the early code for that process).

Who / What: GitLab, Repl.it, Glitch.com, Codestream, Linear, JetBrains
Description: Collaborative software development technology has hence become a significant market segment, with examples such as GitLab, Repl.it, Glitch.com, Codestream, Linear, and JetBrains.
On the incentive side of prediction markets, Gnosis.pm has built “conditional tokens” with richer semantic characteristics that allow more granular enablement of prediction market pricing.

The concept of “superforecasters” has emerged from the crowdsourcing methods, indicating the ability to harness the superior prediction capabilities of specific individuals. GoodJudgment, including its GJOpen, as well as the UK’s government Cosmic Bazaar focus on that.
Specifically, for data scientists, Jupyter, Dominodatalab, Algorithmia, CrewSpark and in a different way Kaggle (data science contests) all enable collaboration at scale.

Use case: Turn open-source into easy-to-adopt enterprise software
Description: Data science and information technology leverage virtual collaboration. Linux showed to the world how a coding environment can be created with rules that enable both solid coding and participatory work – and even spawned an ecosystems of successful private enterprises like RedHat (acquired by IBM) that use and extend that code and add additional services on top of it (eg maintenance.)

Use case: Answer coding questios and share knowledge
Description: StackOverflow is an independent, open community for anyone that codes, with the joint objective to get answers to the toughest coding questions, share knowledge with coworkers in private (and find a job, which acts as a powerful motivator). Other software vendors have been collaboration communities for many years, such as SAP Community Network.

Use case: Solve life sciences and pharma challenges
Description: MIT-linked Community Bio is aiming at creating a global “movement” that can reimagine how science can be done. Starting from a core of synthetic biology, its modus operandi is “anti-disciplinary”, in that it not just brings together hundreds of people from very different disciplines but also encourages thinking of solutions that could redefine the future of those disciplines, on the premise that solutions will require a radical rethinking of the boundaries of those methods. It does so sometime in person, but more often virtually through a mix of synchronous and asynchronous tools. The community concept and some of the participants was leveraged during the Covid-19 pandemic to generate new ideas as part of a MIT CoLab in collaboration with healthcare equipment manufacturer MilliporeSigma.

Use case: Do data science work in neuroscience
Description: Eyewire is a science project where volunteers help neuroscientists to map the neural connections of the brain, taken through an electronic microscope. As AI-enabled computer vision and related machine learning will improve, the volunteers’ input will likely be able to train the next generation of machines so that they can “finish the job”, at scale, and ask human input only for exceptions.

Who / What: FabLabs, Arduino, Hackster.io, Wikifactory, OpenBCI.com, The Open Source Pharma Foundation
Description: Even engineering, life sciences, and neuroscience and more generally “hacker- and maker- spaces” (such as Fab Labs, where participants collectively hack practical problems with scrappy, limited resources, as part of the so-called “maker movement) have their participatory, collective intelligence networks. Arduino’s community (open-source electronic prototyping platform enabling users to create interactive electronic objects), Hackster.io (“a community dedicated to learning hardware, from beginner to pro, where participants can share their projects and learn from other developers”), Wikifactory and OpenBCI.com (dedicated to brain computer interfaces) and are three examples. The Open Source Pharma Foundation181, in India, attempts to use open source methods to share data and processes to generate breakthroughs in the field of life sciences.

Another attempt to give large, decentralized life sciences and possibly other scientific communities new methods for doing research, JOGL (Just One Giant Lab) has created a technology platform that enables sharing of resources and attempts to provide the foundational infrastructure needed for participatory and decentralized innovation.

“A community of makers, designers, engineers, experts and creative problem solvers who innovate globally, and produce locally [to overcome] existing supply chains and intellectual property restrictions, to get the right products in the right hands, wherever they're needed.”

Use case: Train and annotate data for machine learning models
Description: Google AutoML, which helps developers to train sophisticated models and can even provide them with (often crowdsourced) annotation of data

Synapse.org helps researches organize their digital research assets, get credit for their research, and collaborate with others, through a platform that enables structured sharing. Multi-purpose scientific research support platform particularly focused on enabling collaboration and sharing.

Android and iOS enabled millions of people to create mobile technology code. Gaming communities are among the most interesting new developments in this space. Importantly, these environments exercise some element of quality control – most famously through the comparatively slow process that Apple follows before allowing apps on its AppStore.
Nintendo’s Animal Crossing, a life-simulation game with its own currency and central bank. Collaboration through videogames, virtual, and augmented reality

Use case: Combine shared virtual spaces with data-driven simulations
Description: Engineering and design companies are attempting to build immersive “digital twins” that combine the ability of users to experience virtual spaces without the limitations of physical location, together with the possibility of data-driven simulations. Nvidia, one of the leading manufacturers of high-power processing units (and the inventor of the GPU), has recently launched its Omniverse environment to cater to these possibilities.

Use case: Enable collaborative 3D model where people can work together
Description: The Wild is possibly the first current example of fully collaborative 3D models where people can work together in a virtual space to gain insight on anything from architecture to product design. Real time, immersive collaboration holds the promise of providing a three-dimensional canvas, and an emotional immediacy that traditional virtual spaces don’t have.

Colony.io attempts to create a protocol for interoperability between an emerging set of technologies based on Ethereum, for instance, and is focused on the management of the human resources – in contrast to Augur (predictions), golem.network (distributed computing power) and 0x.org (exchange of tokens).

Use case: Democratize natural language analysis, resulting in better search and trend analysis etc.
Description: Enablers of hyperconnectivity rarely use artificial intelligence on natural language for anything more than basic search, grammar and spellcheck. This is a gap, given the important role that language plays in enabling large groups of people to innovate and learn together. Natural language processing (NLP) however has improved the ability for people to exchange large knowledge sets, by enabling for instance better search functions. Tools like EyeOnText simplify data science on text analytics. Text “x-ray” like what’s done by Amazon Kindle allow the automatic creation of themes that humans can peruse and recombine.
McKinsey’s OrgLab enables many people to collaboratively design the organizational structure during a redesign effort

There are some experimental examples of platforms intended to create radically new organizational structures, whereby people work on the tasks that they like and they’re competent for, and they get fairly rewarded for it. They borrow some of the concepts of holocracy (used for instance at retailer Zappos, software firm Satalia, or to an extent videogames producer Valve).

Semantic MediaWiki “is a free, open-source extension to MediaWiki – the wiki software that powers Wikipedia – that lets you store and query data within the wiki's pages”. Semantic web where knowledge can be assembled, mapped, tagged, structured to search for content in a more effective way

“The Underlay is a global, distributed graph of public knowledge. [...] This is an attempt to replicate the richness of private knowledge graphs in a public, decentralized manner." Semantic web where knowledge can be assembled, mapped, tagged, structured to search for content in a more effective way.

Use case: Enable cybersecurity for a distributed collaboration and processing environment
Description: Corporations that handle sensitive information usually adopt Microsoft technologies that promise a stronger control. However, some of these collaboration environments lack multiple-factor security that more traditional tools guarantee. Security will become available at a cost – namely privacy. The trust that individuals and companies put into data aggregation services is generally low, or even very low as in the case of healthcare. Some solutions may be able to scale thanks to blockchain: Ocean Protocol enables  transaction to happen closer to sensitive data, behind a protection wall; Singapore announced an APEX common API for allowing public agencies to share data with public and private organizations.

Use case: Optimize allocation of resources (people and machines' time...) to tasks
Description: Where appropriate and possible allocate work deliberately, for instance with a sort of ticketing system whose algorithm matches resources with tasks. It is also possible for contributors to decide where to work out of the open tasks. In the examples Wikipedia and Linux, for instance, the latter option is adopted, but contributions are subjugated to contributors having the right credentials.

Use case: Reach out to communities and networks
Description: At the same time, a strong “marketing” muscle can help. Outreach tools, starting with social media (e.g. Dux-soup, Followers DM, or Sprinklr.) They can also start celebrating punctuations of the lifecycle of the new network (think of what Change.org does), and in general create an amount of drumbeat that makes the network’s pulse felt.

Use case: Engage with networks of people through bots
Description: Large groups of people can and increasingly will be initially engaged by bots, that can execute a simplified yet human-like conversation with the targets, taking an example from recruitment campaigns that have started utilizing such tools (e.g. Kriya.ai, Talkpush).

In-person contacts have positive roles where applicable, such as where there’s enough critical mass in a specific locale to justify the creation of a “local chapter” of sorts – Meetup.com or tools like Eventbrite are obvious candidates.

Use case: Collaborate remotely in synchronous (or semi-synchronous) meetings
Description: Virtual canvases to collect ideas may allow synchronous collaboration in large groups. Synchronous (or semi-synchronous) collaboration in small to medium-sized (under 50) groups.

Use case: Collaborate on text and image content
Description: Utilizing examples from diverse fields, including somewhat unrelated ones, can foster creative ideas. This can be done in a scalable, collective way through mindmaps, Google Docs, Mural.ly, Padlet, etc. Human-machine approaches could eventually be used too. Collective intelligence design tools, enabling synchronous or asynchronous collaboration in the form of idea (text) sharing and commingling.

in 2019 Takeda launched a highly unusual initiative, spearheaded by Magda Schoeneich, leader of the company’s Center for Scientific Leadership and Innovation. Inspired by a decade of research at MIT, Takeda identified a specific and particularly difficult healthcare challenge – depression in Japan – to test-drive new ways to improve healthcare and build leadership capabilities. It chose a cadre of executives to experiment with new ways of designing patient solutions based on superminds. Takeda’s big question: how can superminds be part of healthcare’s future? This process helped innovators think in systems, and effectively acted as an extension of design-thinking innovation techniques. Takeda gained a cadre of executives experienced in these methods, able to propagate them within the company through their own networks.

Use case: Limit algorithmic bias in social media
Description: Because individual brains are biased towards exaggerated or outlandish claims and amplified by algorithms which maximize web-browsing stickiness, social networks have the tendency to propagate negative and false information. As an example, The Economist created a Twitter “clone” bot of US President in 2020, and watched how the algorithm favored polarized content when recommending conten

Who / What: Factmata.com, fullfact.org, Disinformation Lab, Citizen Evidence Lab, Snopes.com
Description: Bolster fact-checking platforms in a partly automated fashion using natural language analysis and network-credibility analytics such as Factmata.com or fullfact.org, the European Union’s Disinformation Lab, Amnesty International’s Citizen Evidence Lab which collects and compares additional metadata (such as location, weather), Snopes.com, or partly crowdsourced

Use case: Limit spreading of falsehoods on social media
Description: Singapore’s government in 2019 enforced regulations that require labeling of social network posts that spread falsehoods, for example. During the Covid-19 pandemic, social media tagged misinformation, partially with the help of users who surfaced suspicious information early. In general, research has shown that relatively small groups of laypeople can identify factual bias from small amounts of text, such as titles and subtitles, which bodes well for machine-enhanced crowdsourcing of fact checking.

Use case: Moderate and limit bias of social media content
Description: AI only knows what it is taught by the data it is fed and how it is trained on that data. Bias can creep into both. For example, AI learns bias if the sample data inadvertently excludes certain ethnicities, or if a small AI team passes on its own bias. AI deployment for network information should have processes and governance that minimize mistakes leading to bias. Facebook, for instance, is starting down this path with its content moderation oversight body.

Regulate the field and introduce stiffer legal deterrence against willful disinformation. And possibly, follow Estonia in formalizing a “digital ID” that accompanies our most sensitive activities on the web. A version of that (stricter requirements for identity verification) was introduced in early 2020 by Google, in an effort to prevent political misinformation on its advertising platforms

Use case: Protect individual data ownership based on public good guidelines
Description: Data trusts, where the rules are decided based on public good and guidelines shared, are another step in this direction. Open Data Institute and various national governments as well as the European Commission, are moving in that direction.

Use case: Protect individual data ownership based on blockchain and other tools, and self-regulation
Description: One of the founding fathers of the web, Tim Berners-Lee, has spearheaded the creation of a set of methods and tools, called Solid, for ensuring individual data ownership. Other initiative, such as blockchain-based Rainfall.one, attempt to address the same challenge, with the added value to promote monetization for the end users in exchange for the data they create. Self-regulation is also a possibility – if internet players move advertising revenue away from selling advertising based on tracked individual tracking history.
Enabling the consumption of larger quantities of information by people

Use case: Simplifying asynchronous communication by helping people write in English
Description: Grammarly and Hemingway App support good writing, and their algorithms might help to streamline our verbiage. Textio, on the other hand is an app that is used to craft language that avoids gender bias.

Use case: Enable concise transfer of knowledge and alignment across network
Description: Amazon’s founder Jeff Bezos famously enforces a concise format for meeting memos, which are religiously read by participants prior to the start of the meeting. Many companies have adopted it.

Use case: Generate more visuals and engaging narrative
Description: Most books, articles, even PowerPoint decks are mostly words. But a picture is worth a thousand words, especially if accompanied by some textual context. That’s why PowerPoint caught on in the first place. That’s why so many got enthusiastic about Prezi.

Google Translate has evolved from inaccurate and grammatically primitive, to  accurate enough to convey meaning in many situations. In many respects, its evolution rests on an exercise of mining collective intelligence, as noted by Richard Baldwin “the EU Joint Research Center posted a dataset with human-translated sentences in 22 languages (over 1 billion words). Not to be outdone, the EU Parliament released a dataset with 1.3 billion paragraphs that had been translated into 23 EU languages. Another massive database, uploaded by the Canadian Parliament, has millions of paired, human-translated sentences from the parliamentarian debates. With data and the computer power to process it, Google translations improved more in a month than they had in the previous four years.”

Speakers of languages like Chinese and English, where the corpus of data is large and the language translation more accurate, will become more interoperable. Speakers of language with a vast corpus of language data for management, science and engineering applications (Japanese, German, French, Russian) will also benefit. With companies like Appen and Lionbridge continuing to use crowdsourcing to enhance translation algorithms for specialized uses, other languages may quickly become available for machine-assisted translations. Soon, Spanish, Italian, or Indonesian speakers could see their accented English recognized more accurately by translation apps, limiting the need for machine translation of their native languages.

Synchronous communication between people who speak different languages isn’t a far-fetched, futuristic dream. Google, Timkettle and Waverly earbuds, as well as Skype real-time translation have debuted and shown potential despite their current limits. The difference between 90% and 98% accuracy isn’t 8%, it feels more like multiple times better. It is just a matter of time to get there, especially for standard language. And for now, some videoconferencing providers such as Zoom offer real-time translation as an additional service.
